utterances: For example, they say Putin had many - has had many positive experiences working with Western political leaders whose business interests made them more disposed to deal with Russia, such as Berlusconi of Italy and Schroeder of Germany.
That paragraph will invite an awful lot of new reporting.
Now, one thing, E.J.
- I want to jump in here because even before Donald Trump got his briefing, he was calling the inquiries into this a political witch hunt.
And I want to get your sense from the two of you about the relationship between Trump and the security community after this week.
Well, first of all, I think Trump's relationship with Russia is only further underscored by this report.
He has refused over and over again to even allow that the Russians were trying to influence the election.
And he's stayed very pro-Putin right through to this moment.
That already creates problems for the intelligence community.
They're talking about, in the Trump camp, of reorganizing U.S.
intelligence.
Some of that could be bureaucratic.
But in this case, you started to worry, is he trying to defang parts of this community?
Right, David Brooks...
Well, first we're seeing all of American policy being distorted by the gravitational pull of Trump's ego.
He wants to take full credit for this election, and the idea of the Russians may have helped him, more of a line, is an insult to his sense of self.
And so he's very sensitive to the thought that he got any help in winning this election.
But there's a larger and substantive issue, especially within the Republican Party.
The Republican Party, including Paul Ryan and John McCain and others, have always basically believed in the post-war global international order - the organizations, like NATO that we built.
And they've considered Russia a threat to it and a threat to the Democratic alliances.
Now, before I let you go, I want to just touch on one more thing because Congress was back this week.
And before the members of the House could even hang up their coats, you had Mike Pence and President Obama up on the House laying out the strategy on Obamacare.
So they're sort of opening salvos in that battle.
Meji, let me ask you about money, because Senator Clinton's campaign, according to the Washington Post today, is 20 million dollars in debt.
That means that not only has she put in 11 million dollars of her own money that she might not get back, but also there are advisors who haven't been paid.
And there's also talk of whether or not Senator Obama should actually, you now, kick her the cash and say hey, you know, here, peace and blessings, be gone.
What do you think of that?
I think she's just wasting her time, you know, like putting her own money in there.
I think she should just step out of the race because she keeps on, like, once you have to put your own money in, you are not getting any donations, you're really just wasting your time in my opinion.
Shay...
Like Obama's gets ...
Oh, please go ahead.

Obama has been getting donations, and he's been getting a lot of money is for his - like, for his campaign, and he doesn't feel like he has to put his own money in there so I think she's just pulling the wrong strings, in my opinion.
Shay, it's funny, you know, here on the show we get letters from Clinton supporters saying that we're too pro-Obama and for Obama supporters saying that we're too pro-Clinton.

I know we'll get letters about this but what I want to do to follow up on that money question is, you know, I talked to someone who was an Obama supporter, and she said under no circumstances should my campaign donations go to Hillary Clinton.
What do you think of that campaign argument?
Even if it made it easier for Senator Obama to get the nomination if he paid those debts, and this is all speculation, but it's speculation by a lot of political insiders.
Do you think that Obama supporters would be unhappy if their money went to pay off Senator Clinton's debts?

I don't think so, because I think they would understand in terms of, I would assume their long term goal which is to get Obama, and if not Obama, a Democrat into the White House, they would understand that strategic maneuver, if you will.
So I think that people would be maybe a little upset in the beginning, but would understand that's what Obama has to do, if he has to do that, in order to get Hillary Clinton out of the race.
Jay, the West Virginia primary is on Tuesday, and Senator Clinton's ahead in the polls, so do you think that this counteracts your argument that the race is over for her?
The race is over, I mean how many, there are 40 some delegates I believe up for play tomorrow in West Virginia.

It's just - again it's prolonging the inevitable, and I think overall I know you're probably going to mention the whole soundbite that Senator Clinton came out last week about the hardworking Americans.

And I don't know, obviously she'll probably have a very healthy victory tomorrow, but it kind of goes back to, you know, her comments about having the support of hard working white Americans as if those are the only people whose votes matter.
I don't know.
I thought that inference was just ridiculous.
I'm not saying it's overtly racist, but there are just some things that are better left unsaid.
They there may be some truth to it, but you can't just say that type of stuff.
And you know - please go head.

Oh, OK, I just wanted to piggy back off of that, you know I definitely agree that Clinton should be rightfully criticized, and has been for that heard working white Americans comment which implies that black voters or affluent white voters, educated whites, aren't hard workers.
I certainly understand the offense taken with that.
But I think she was correct in that her base of support is potentially broader than that of Obama's, and Obama has not been fully vetted yet.

And I think that that's part of the reason why there's some superdelegates who are kind of on hold to see how it plays out, even though it looks like Obama will get the nomination because of the pledged delegates and such.

But because Clinton has her base of working class whites, Hispanics, and white women, that is potentially a broader base than the kind of McGovernesque base that Obama has going into the general election.
Because black voters, no matter what, are going to support the Democratic nominee 90 to 10 anyway.
And that's what Clinton is counting on.
White working class voters, and Hispanics are more swing voters.
I just dislike the categorization of white voters as working class, they're upper class, they're blue collar, they're middle American.
Their NASCAR dads, they're soccer moms.
If you're black, you're just black.
I mean, it's just again, it's an insult to the intelligence of the typical voter to assume that, again, a person is genetically predisposed to vote for a certain candidate.
I just think again, that's hilarious and to consider the fact that this may be a person that could possibly be the president in the fall.
I just don't like that type of politics and I think it's time to move beyond that.
Meji let me get...
(Unintelligible)
Shay, let me get Meji in here.
Democrats have struggled with attracting white voters, you know, frankly for the last four decades.
And President Bush beat John Kerry by 17 points with white voters, Al Gore by 12 points among white voters.
Even President Clinton didn't get the votes, the majority of white male votes.

So do you think that there is just a situation where the Democrats can't, whether it's a winning president like Clinton or a losing candidate like Kerry that the Democrats can't count of the white vote carrying them to victory?

Well, I mean, my opinion I think most of the like people in the country, the white people are Republicans and it's just not going to - they won't win off the white vote itself so Democrats need, like, also they need black vote, they need, like, a lot of people's votes.

And what I was going to say about, they were saying about Hillary only being interested in the white vote in those states, I just think that, you know, America is more than white, it's a mesh of different cultures, and she should like focus her campaign on all the races instead of just talk about how hardworking people are white.
Look...
Her being...
I think Donald Trump and Steve Bannon, his chief ideologist, do not think that way.
They think of Russia as a potential ally in the war against ISIS.
And they don't particularly value the post-war global international order.

And so we could - aside from the personal nature, there's a deep ideological rift here which could be seeing the attempt to really change American grand strategy with Russia turning into an ally and not a foe.
I actually want to reintroduce who's talking and what we're doing.
This is NPR's News and Notes.
I'm Farai Chideya.
And we were just hearing from Meji Alabi who blogs at anythingblack.net.
This is part of today's Blogger's Roundtable.
We've also got Jay Andersen who blogs at avergaebro.com, and Shay Riley who writes for bookerrising.blogspot.com.
And I want to make sure, we have two more topics, I want to make sure that we have time to get to them.
So Meji, I'm going to ask you about something completely different.
Jury selection finally started on the R.
Kelly child pornography case.
Attorneys for the prosecution and defense are expected to continue questioning 150 potential jurors.
That started on Friday, and Kelly entered the court on Friday to cheers and jeers.
It's been six years since the R&B star was charged with having sex with an underage girl and videotaping it.
That tape was downloaded to the internet, watched by people all over the country.
Now Meji, how old are you again?
Nineteen.
You're 19 years old, so you are in a demographic that where R.
Kelly has been around as a recording star for pretty much your whole life.
What are people your age saying about the R.
Kelly case?
Well, to tell the truth, people think the whole case is played out.
It's kind of old.
You know, it's been six years, I mean took him way too long to get to trial.
He's been waiting to go the courthouse for, you know, the last five years and I think, most people think he didn't do it, but, I mean, it's clear that he did do it.
I think he probably won't get convicted, but that's just how it is.
Jay, do you think it's that most people think he didn't do it, or most people are willing to forgive a celebrity anything.
Come one.
Let's keep it real in here again.
Yes he did it.
I mean there's a tape out there.
I haven't seen it.
As a reporter I have to say it's alleged, but you say.
I haven't seen it, but I've heard enough people who've said they've seen it, and hey if it walks like a duck, it is probably a duck.
Let's just be honest about why R.
Kelly is still walking free six years later.
He is a celebrity who happens to make a lot of other people a lot of money.
If this was some, you know, one hit wonder like, I don't know, Albe Shore or something, he'd be under the jail, by now, but he is not.
I think Al had at least two hits.
Al had two hits.
OK.
(Soundbite of laughter)
I'll Point Your Own Girl,"" and ""Night and Day."" OK, two hits, but still, the fact is R.
Kelly make so many other people money.
I think again, that's what's given him the six year pass, and has allowed him to just keep making records.
But, you know, its time to pay the pie, a pie for R&B now.
He is going to do his time.
Shay, the alleged victim is now 23 years old, and she says that she wasn't the girl in the tape.
So what do you make of that?
Well I haven't seen the tape, so I can't determine whether or not that is true.
But I've never been an R.
Kelly fan, anyway.
But I suspect that she is saying that because of potential negative publicity that would come her way, or she has, you know, been told to keep quiet, so to speak.
But, you know, the trial is definitely in the news here.
In Chicago, it's everywhere, because R.
Kelly is from Chicago.

And to me, how I look at the case, it just seems like it's another example of how alleged perpetrators of crime, especially if they are celebrities, are given preference over alleged black crime victims, especially if they are females, so my - that kind of raises the cackles, if you will, of my moderate-conservative-libertarian feminism.
And another issue is that you don't see many people within the black community who are willing to publicly chastise R.
Kelly, you know, for this alleged crime, and how that relates to his celebrity and to gender.
There are a couple of guys who tried to protest, here in Chicago, and they were basically shut down by R.
Kelly supporters, who seem to revere his celebrity so much, that they're not even willing to entertain the possibility that he may have done this crime.
I want to move on to one last topic.
Last week, in Philadelphia, a local Fox TV helicopter videotaped at least twelve, mostly white, officers beating three black men suspected in a shooting.
That beating happened near an area where police officers were conducting a man hunt.
They were looking for a suspect in a bank robbery.
Two days earlier, a Philadelphia police officer was shot to death.
Now, Jay, some people are comparing this to, you know, Rodney King.
That was back in 1991, in Los Angeles.
Do you think it is?
I think it is similar.
I mean, again, if you look at the dynamic of, you know, the Philadelphia case, I think, and this is just my opinion, there seems to be a lot more, there is a lot more grey area here.

I mean, the three gentlemen who were leaving the scene of a crime, or may or may not had been leaving the scene of a crime, you know, it is up in the air, as whether this is a case of mistaken identity.
There was allegedly a fourth individual who got out, and ran away on foot, who might have been tied to a prior police shooting, so, you know, there is so much going on here.

But, I think over all, yes is some of the Rodney King in terms of it being an undeniable case of police brutality, but I think, we, as a community have to get just as upset about the 392 people that were killed in the city of Philadelphia last year, 310 of which were black men.
I mean, I don't know.
It is easy to get upset, and excited about these things when there is a video all over YouTube, but, you know, is one life any more important than others?
I don't think so.
Shay, I mean, how can you talk about this issue, and still also frame the crisis of the murders in Philadelphia, the victims in Philadelphia, like Jay was talking about?
Well, I mean, I think we all agree that, you know, that justice should prevail.

And in this case the cops, you know, had their own kind of justice on these men, and convicted these men from their jumps, so definitely the beating was excessive and there is no excuse for what we so on that videotape.
I think we can still say, hey this was, you know, a very bad situation.
While also say - I don't see this as an either/or - we can also say, you know, look at this 300 and something murders of, you know, black people, black crime victims as well.
And also keep our focus on police brutality when it comes, I don't see it as an either/or situation.
Yeah.
Actually, I haven't, I think I saw it on the news once in San Antonio.
It is not really that big around here, but on the internet, which I am on, you know, every day, I see, I read about it, and I looked at the video.
And I think, like, it is like, this is a case of like street justice, because the police officers lost an officer last week, you know, and they thought it was one of these guys that did it.
And it seemed like a premeditated attack, as if they knew what they were going to do, before they even got to the car, and pulled them out.
And they were just, you know, kicking them, like, violently.
It looked like almost a gang jumping, but it was police officers.
So, I mean, they thought they are above the law, and it was them dealing their own justice.
